BURIDI, ABDUL G, MD-NEP - Patient MWF HD, need HD orders for inpatient HD ELKIN GALVIS-LEON

Primary Discharge Diagnosis
Injured right hand s/p fall

Secondary Diagnosis(es)
ICM, HFrEF (ICM-TTE-11/2020-EF-29%), s/p HM3 as DT on 2021-10-24, CAD s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014, HTN, T2DM, COPD and OSA, CKD stage 4, HD MWF, RLE cellulitis and pain

Discharge Follow Up
Kevin DUNBAR MATOS - 2022-05-01 13:00
ELKIN GALVIS-LEON - Within 5 to 7 days

To Do's/Follow Up:
Resume VNA home health orders for in home care.
Continue outpatient HD on MWF with Davita Dialysis.
Ensure patient follows up with Hand Team (Dr. Galvis-Leon) within 5-7 days.
New medications:
Considered stopping Isodril 30 mg PO TID, but will keep (this is not a new med, although it looks this way on DC summary)
Starting Allopurinol 100 mg PO to be taken on dialysis days, MWF AFTER dialysis is completed. Patient requested something for gout prophylaxis.

Code Status
Start: 2022-04-09 21:53:00 EDT, Full Code, Continuous Order

Patient presented the night of 2022-04-09 complaining of right hand pain. He stated he was walking home from the grocery store on 2022-04-07 and he felt dizzy and tripped over uneven concrete. He did not hit his head and he did not have LOC. He caught himself on his R knee and outstretched R hand. He had pain in these areas since then but did not require any OTC medications for pain control. However, the pain continued to be present and worsening until he called the ambulance to be taken to the ED. He also has limited movement of his R fingers for full extension. He has numbness in his fingertips but otherwise has no neurovascular complaints.

Mr. Parker was seen in the ER and received x-rays of the right wrist and the right knee. He then received a CT of the right wrist WO for further evaluation. See findings below. Hand Surgery team was consulted and they tentatively scheduled surgery for the morning of 2022-04-10 to repair the suspected dislocation of the right metacarpal. Eliquis was held, patient made NPO. The morning of 2022-04-10 Hand Surgery team decided surgery was not necessary. Patient was given a brace and instructed to elevate hand to relieve swelling. He was prescribed pain medication and Hand Team wanted to watch his swelling overnight. At that point we res his Eliquis. On 2022-04-11, Dr. Buridi was consulted to place orders for patients regularly scheduled dialysis treatment to be done while inpatient. Labs drawn, ordered placed and patient was taken down to dialysis around 1500. He completed HD around 1900, he tolerated well and 4L were removed. We did DC Isodril due to patients complaints of dizziness and near-syncope but during HD his MAP's remained elevated at 96-102, we will continue all meds as previously prescribed. He returned to his room and Hand Team okay'd for DC with a follow up within 5-7 days. When patient was told he was okay'd for DC he did not feel comfortable with his pain regimen and the brace he was given by Hand did not fit, he asked if he could be released in the morning after seeing them again. This morning he is stable from a VAD stand point, his VS and labs are stable. He is able to make all connections for his VAD with his left hand and right arm as the stabilizer. He is eating and drinking okay. He is still complaining of pain and limited ROM in the right hand. The hand team is obtaining a better fitting brace today and asked to follow up with him outpatient in 5-7 days. He has an appointment with the VAD office on 2022-05-01 that he will keep and his home health orders will resume. Patient seen by and discussed care with Dr. Dunbar Matos.
Radiology:
CR Wrist Min 3 Vws RT: FINDINGS: There is no displaced fracture. The alignment is anatomic. No soft tissue abnormality is seen. Moderate degenerative changes of the first CMC joint. IMPRESSION: No acute osseous abnormality.
CR Knee AP LAT RT: FINDINGS: There is no displaced fracture. The alignment is anatomic. No soft tissue abnormality is seen. There is no joint effusion. IMPRESSION: No acute osseous abnormality. CT UE RT WO: I MPRESSION: 1. Slight bony irregularity at the inferior aspect of the posterior portion of the triquetrum, which could represent an age indeterminant fracture. Recommend clinical correlation for any associated point tenderness to help assess acuity/significance. 2. Findings of chondrocalcinosis appear to be present, with probably related to pyrophosphate arthropathy, as described above. The degenerative changes appear to be severe at the first carpometacarpal joint and at the second proximal interphalangeal joint, with other joints involved, as above. 3. Scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm, which could be normal or be indicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity or ligamentous disruption. Recommend clinical correlation. 4. Generalized nonspecific soft tissue swelling. 5. Peripheral arterial calcifications, which can be seen with diabetes

Assessment and Plan: Mr. Parker fell 4 days ago and caught himself with his right hand, it had been swollen and painful since. He came into the ER 8/9 for the right hand pain and also has limited movement of his R fingers for full extension. Initial exam showed dislocation of metacarpal bone, hand surgery team was consulted and made patient NPO, held Eliquis and planned for surgery yesterday morning to repair injury. Hand team felt surgery may not be necessary, they gave patient a split and instructed him to elevate hand to reduce swelling. Eliquis restarted and waiting for hand to ok for DC. Completed schedule HD inpatient today. Discussed and seen with Dr. Dunbar Matos.

Result: Name: Michael Daniel PARKERMRN: D002087077FIN: D2122101649Accession No: 01CT210012549Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03 Age: 51 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2022-04-09 7:02 PMStudy Description: CT UE RT WOAttending Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANOrdering Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANEXAMINATION: CT of the right upper extremity. No intravenous contrast wasadministered.PROVIDED INDICATION: Pain.COMPARISON: CT of the right upper extremity performed 2022-01-03.TECHNIQUE: Axial, coronal, sagittal, and three-dimensional CT images of the right handwere submitted.FINDINGS: Subtle amorphus calcification of the triangular fibrocartilage complex region,suggestive of chondrocalcinosis. There is also severe degeneration of the firstcarpometacarpal joint, moderate degeneration of the first metacarpophalangeal joint,and at least moderate degenerative changes at the second and third metacarpophalangealjoints. Severe degenerative change, probably with some crystalling deposition andperhaps erosions at the second proximal interphalangeal joint. Otherwise milddegenerative changes. There is some nonspecific bony fragmentation in the region ofthe pisiform bone, similar to the prior examination. Slight bony irregularity at theinferior aspect of the posterior portion of the triquetrum, which could represent anage indeterminant fracture. There are mild to moderate degenerative changes at theradiocarpal joint, posteriorly. The scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm,which could be normal or be indicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity orligamentous disruption. There is limited soft tissue evaluation due to the lack ofintravenous contrast administration. However, the soft tissues do appear to begenerally edematous, of uncertain underlying etiology. Peripheral arterialcalcifications noted in the ulnar artery, which can be seen with diabetes.IMPRESSION:1. Slight bony irregularity at the inferior aspect of the posterior portion of thetriquetrum, which could represent an age indeterminant fracture. Recommend clinicalcorrelation for any associated point tenderness to help assess acuity/significance.2. Findings of chondrocalcinosis appear to be present, with probably related topyrophosphate arthropathy, as described above. The degenerative changes appear to besevere at the first carpometacarpal joint and at the second proximal interphalangealjoint, with other joints involved, as above.3. Scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm, which could be normal or beindicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity or ligamentous disruption. Recommendclinical correlation.4. Generalized nonspecific soft tissue swelling.5. Peripheral arterial calcifications, which can be seen with diabetes.Dictated by:Dr Jonathan JoshiDictated DT/TM: 2022-04-09 11:00 PMSigned by: Dr Jonathan JoshiSigned DT/TM: 2022-04-09 11:13 PMEditor: DT/TM:

Result: Name: Michael Daniel PARKERMRN: D002087077FIN: D2122101649Accession No: 01CT210012549Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03 Age: 51 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2022-04-09 7:02 PMStudy Description: CT UE RT WOAttending Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANOrdering Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWANEXAMINATION: CT of the right upper extremity. No intravenous contrast wasadministered.PROVIDED INDICATION: Pain.COMPARISON: CT of the right upper extremity performed 2022-01-03.TECHNIQUE: Axial, coronal, sagittal, and three-dimensional CT images of the right handwere submitted.FINDINGS: Subtle amorphus calcification of the triangular fibrocartilage complex region,suggestive of chondrocalcinosis. There is also severe degeneration of the firstcarpometacarpal joint, moderate degeneration of the first metacarpophalangeal joint,and at least moderate degenerative changes at the second and third metacarpophalangealjoints. Severe degenerative change, probably with some crystalling deposition andperhaps erosions at the second proximal interphalangeal joint. Otherwise milddegenerative changes. There is some nonspecific bony fragmentation in the region ofthe pisiform bone, similar to the prior examination. Slight bony irregularity at theinferior aspect of the posterior portion of the triquetrum, which could represent anage indeterminant fracture. There are mild to moderate degenerative changes at theradiocarpal joint, posteriorly. The scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm,which could be normal or be indicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity orligamentous disruption. There is limited soft tissue evaluation due to the lack ofintravenous contrast administration. However, the soft tissues do appear to begenerally edematous, of uncertain underlying etiology. Peripheral arterialcalcifications noted in the ulnar artery, which can be seen with diabetes.IMPRESSION:1. Slight bony irregularity at the inferior aspect of the posterior portion of thetriquetrum, which could represent an age indeterminant fracture. Recommend clinicalcorrelation for any associated point tenderness to help assess acuity/significance.2. Findings of chondrocalcinosis appear to be present, with probably related topyrophosphate arthropathy, as described above. The degenerative changes appear to besevere at the first carpometacarpal joint and at the second proximal interphalangealjoint, with other joints involved, as above.3. Scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm, which could be normal or beindicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity or ligamentous disruption. Recommendclinical correlation.4. Generalized nonspecific soft tissue swelling.5. Peripheral arterial calcifications, which can be seen with diabetes.Dictated by:Dr Jonathan JoshiDictated DT/TM: 2022-04-09 11:00 PMSigned by: Dr Jonathan JoshiSigned DT/TM: 2022-04-09 11:13 PMEditor: DT/TM:

Pt. presents with mechanical fall. He states that he was walking home from the grocery store on 8/7 when he tripped and fell; he did not hit his head and he did not have LOC. He caught himself on his R knee and outstretched R hand. He had pain in these areas since then but did not require any OTC medications for pain control. However, the pain continued to be present and worsening until he called the ambulance to be taken to the ED this evening. He also has limited movement of his R fingers for full extension. He has numbness in his fingertips but otherwise has no neurovascular complaints.

History of Present Illness
51-year-old male with past medical history significant for CHF status post LVAD, COPD, hypertension, diabetes, ESRD on dialysis presents to the ED with complaint of fall, right wrist pain. Patient reports 2 days ago he was ambulating in a grocery store he began to feel lightheaded, dizzy. States he is experienced the symptoms in the past. Ultimately lost his balance secondary to symptoms, falling. States he landed on outstretched right hand. Denies significant blow to the head or loss of consciousness. He did strike his right knee and has abrasions over the right knee occurred. Complains of continued, worsening pain, swelling of the right wrist. Now has difficulty with movement of his digits secondary to swelling and pain. He does have sensation intact, but states he has numbness and tingling of the first, second, third digits. Reports compliance with his medications. No problems with LVAD.

item.paragraph: (CT UE RT WO) Reason For Exam: pain

paragraph.content:
Name: Michael Daniel
mrn:d039010066
fin:x4072550915
accession no:20nl486225949
Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03 Age: 51 years
Study Date/Time: 2022-04-09 7:02 PM
Study Description: CT UE RT WO
Attending Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWAN
Ordering Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWAN
Referring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHY
Primary Care Physician: MD-EMR JENNIFER E MCGOWAN
EXAMINATION: CT of the right upper extremity. No intravenous contrast was
administered.
PROVIDED INDICATION: Pain.
COMPARISON: CT of the right upper extremity performed 2022-01-03.
TECHNIQUE: Axial, coronal, sagittal, and three-dimensional CT images of the right hand
were submitted.
FINDINGS:
Subtle amorphus calcification of the triangular fibrocartilage complex region,
suggestive of chondrocalcinosis. There is also severe degeneration of the first
carpometacarpal joint, moderate degeneration of the first metacarpophalangeal joint,
and at least moderate degenerative changes at the second and third metacarpophalangeal
joints. Severe degenerative change, probably with some crystalling deposition and
perhaps erosions at the second proximal interphalangeal joint. Otherwise mild
degenerative changes. There is some nonspecific bony fragmentation in the region of
the pisiform bone, similar to the prior examination. Slight bony irregularity at the
inferior aspect of the posterior portion of the triquetrum, which could represent an
age indeterminant fracture. There are mild to moderate degenerative changes at the
radiocarpal joint, posteriorly. The scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm,
which could be normal or be indicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity or
ligamentous disruption. There is limited soft tissue evaluation due to the lack of
intravenous contrast administration. However, the soft tissues do appear to be
generally edematous, of uncertain underlying etiology. Peripheral arterial
calcifications noted in the ulnar artery, which can be seen with diabetes.
IMPRESSION:
1. Slight bony irregularity at the inferior aspect of the posterior portion of the
triquetrum, which could represent an age indeterminant fracture. Recommend clinical
correlation for any associated point tenderness to help assess acuity/significance.
2. Findings of chondrocalcinosis appear to be present, with probably related to
pyrophosphate arthropathy, as described above. The degenerative changes appear to be
severe at the first carpometacarpal joint and at the second proximal interphalangeal
joint, with other joints involved, as above.
3. Scapholunate interval measures approximately 3 mm, which could be normal or be
indicative of scapholunate ligamentous laxity or ligamentous disruption. Recommend
clinical correlation.
4. Generalized nonspecific soft tissue swelling.
5. Peripheral arterial calcifications, which can be seen with diabetes.

paragraph.content: Closed Reduction for Metacarpal Dislocation, Care After

text.paragraph:
Closed Reduction for Metacarpal Dislocation, Care After
This sheet gives you information about how to care for yourself after your procedure. Your health care provider may also give you more specific instructions. If you have problems or questions, contact your health care provider.
What can I expect after the procedure?
After the procedure, it is common to have:
• Pain.
• Swelling.
• Stiffness.
• Bruising and discoloration.
• Nausea and drowsiness if you were given sedatives.
Follow these instructions at home:
Medicines
• Take over-the-counter and prescription medicines only as told by your health care provider.
• Ask your health care provider if the medicine prescribed to you requires you to avoid driving or using heavy machinery.
If you have a splint:
• Wear the splint as told by your health care provider. Remove it only as told by your health care provider.
• Loosen the splint if your fingers tingle, become numb, or turn cold and blue.
• Keep the splint clean and dry.
If you have a cast:
• Do not stick anything inside the cast to scratch your skin. Doing that increases your risk of infection.
• Check the skin around the cast every day. Tell your health care provider about any concerns.
• You may put lotion on dry skin around the edges of the cast. Do not put lotion on the skin underneath the cast.
• Keep the cast clean and dry.
Bathing
• Do not take baths, swim, or use a hot tub until your health care provider approves. Ask your health care provider if you may take showers. You may only be allowed to take sponge baths.
• If the splint or cast is not waterproof:
◦ Do not let it get wet.
◦ Cover it with a watertight covering when you take a bath or a shower.
Managing pain, stiffness, and swelling
• If directed, put ice on the injured area.
◦ If you have a removable splint, remove it as told by your health care provider.
◦ Put ice in a plastic bag.
◦ Place a towel between your skin and the bag or between your cast and the bag.
◦ Leave the ice on for 20 minutes, 2–3 times a day.
• Move your fingers often to reduce stiffness and swelling.
• Raise (elevate) the injured area above the level of your heart while you are sitting or lying down. For comfort, you can use a pillow or other object to prop up and support your arm.
Activity
• Return to your normal activities as told by your health care provider. Ask your health care provider what activities are safe for you.
• Do exercises as told by your health care provider.
Driving
• Do not drive for 24 hours if you were given a sedative during your procedure.
• Ask your health care provider when it is safe to drive if you have a splint or cast on your hand.
General instructions
• Do not put pressure on any part of the cast until it is fully hardened. This may take several hours. A splint or cast will remain in place on average between 3 and 6 weeks depending on the injury severity.
• Do not use any products that contain nicotine or tobacco, such as cigarettes, e-cigarettes, and chewing tobacco. These can delay bone healing. If you need help quitting, ask your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your health care provider. This is important.
Contact a health care provider if:
• You have increasing pain or swelling.
• You have increased redness or warmth around any area of the skin.
• You have severe tenderness in any area around or beneath the cast.
• You have increased numbness of the fingers.
• Your splint or cast is damaged or becomes too loose.
Get help right away if:
• You have sudden pain or pain that is much worse than before.
• Your fingers turn cold or blue.
• You have new swelling in the upper portion of your arm.
Summary
• After this procedure, it is common to have pain, swelling, stiffness, and bruising.
• Follow your health care provider's instructions for taking care of yourself at home as you recover.
• You may be told how take care of your splint or cast, when to return to normal activities, and how to use ice to reduce pain and swelling.
• Contact a health care provider if you have increasing pain, swelling, warmth, or redness, or if your fingers become numb.
• Get help right away if you have sudden or worsening pain, or your fingers turn cold or blue.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-08-04 Document Reviewed: 2020-08-04
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.

paragraph.content: Cast or Splint Care, Adult, Easy-to-Read

text.paragraph:
Cast or Splint Care, Adult
Casts and splints are supports that are worn to protect broken bones and other injuries. A cast or splint may hold a bone still and in the correct position while it heals. Casts and splints may also help to ease pain, swelling, and muscle spasms.
How to care for your cast
• Do not stick anything inside the cast to scratch your skin.
• Check the skin around the cast every day. Tell your doctor about any concerns.
• You may put lotion on dry skin around the edges of the cast. Do not put lotion on the skin under the cast.
• Keep the cast clean.
• If the cast is not waterproof:
◦ Do not let it get wet.
◦ Cover it with a watertight covering when you take a bath or a shower.
How to care for your splint
• Wear it as told by your doctor. Take it off only as told by your doctor.
• Loosen the splint if your fingers or toes tingle, get numb, or turn cold and blue.
• Keep the splint clean.
• If the splint is not waterproof:
◦ Do not let it get wet.
◦ Cover it with a watertight covering when you take a bath or a shower.
Follow these instructions at home:
Bathing
• Do not take baths or swim until your doctor says it is okay. Ask your doctor if you can take showers. You may only be allowed to take sponge baths for bathing.
• If your cast or splint is not waterproof, cover it with a watertight covering when you take a bath or shower.
Managing pain, stiffness, and swelling
• Move your fingers or toes often to avoid stiffness and to lessen swelling.
• Raise (elevate) the injured area above the level of your heart while sitting or lying down.
Safety
• Do not use the injured limb to support your body weight until your doctor says that it is okay.
• Use crutches or other assistive devices as told by your doctor.
General instructions
• Do not put pressure on any part of the cast or splint until it is fully hardened. This may take many hours.
• Return to your normal activities as told by your doctor. Ask your doctor what activities are safe for you.
• Keep all follow-up visits as told by your doctor. This is important.
Contact a doctor if:
• Your cast or splint gets damaged.
• The skin around the cast gets red or raw.
• The skin under the cast is very itchy or painful.
• Your cast or splint feels very uncomfortable.
• Your cast or splint is too tight or too loose.
• Your cast becomes wet or it starts to have a soft spot or area.
• You get an object stuck under your cast.
Get help right away if:
• Your pain gets worse.
• The injured area tingles, gets numb, or turns blue and cold.
• The part of your body above or below the cast is swollen and it turns a different color (is discolored).
• You cannot feel or move your fingers or toes.
• There is fluid leaking through the cast.
• You have very bad pain or pressure under the cast.
• You have trouble breathing.
• You have shortness of breath.
• You have chest pain.
This information is not intended to replace advice given to you by your health care provider. Make sure you discuss any questions you have with your health care provider.
Document Revised: 2020-12-08 Document Reviewed: 2018-08-08
Elsevier Patient Education © 2020 Elsevier Inc.
